Cell.Data: So I do have a history of acoustic instruments with the trumpet.
basic ideas of pitches, rhythms and harmony
I've always been primarily into music and but also sound and soundscape and that sort of thing.
And then I realized that there was this use of technology to create sound that where the sound was more important than the instrument.
So it started from their results

When I was in high school and so on finding out about John Cage and Iannis Xenakis and those kind of things during that period of 15 to 18, I decided that oh, and I also, you know, learned early on about.
So I decided that the microphone, the recording device tapes were going to be my instrument.

But those were my media, so I, you know, I got a four track, I got effects processors. I got a microphone, super cheap, low tech stuff. And I worked with that stuff a lot in that, you know, 1516 to 18 time period. Then I amplified it. When I went to undergrad.
I didn't go to the School of Music because I wasn't playing instrument. I went for math, but I realized they had electronic music studio with a long history
a korg MS-20 had analog synthesizers and tape machines reel to reel tape machines

So then I was going back to the synthesizer, you know, engaging the synthesizer and tape reel to reel tape recording multitrack tape recording as a primary medium. I bought a cord MS-2000 precisely because it had a vocoder built into it.

I got the vocoder, I already had samplers and things like that, so modulation between voice and recorded objects became one step closer to a performative thing like I would set up and perform things in studio as part of set them to tape and then layer them.
So that period of 18 to 22 was definitely still like music, concrete, tape manipulation, type things. Composer in the studio. But Performatively engaging the studio.
, but I love this sensor based stuff. Met Pauline Oliveros, saw that she was playing an accordion that had expansion to it, and then I retroactively looked back
I was playing the studio and she was doing this in the 60s.
And then I found out about David Tudor more than just cage and learned about the boxes and the notion of feedback and systems.

So that was one point of inspiration and the other one was, you know, the book microsound came out and granular synthesis is becoming a lot more flexible around 2000, let's say 2001, 2002. And I was that aesthetically had me start thinking about. The notion of the grain and granular clouds and Curtis roads

Code that you know that was happening and then I thought, OK, I'm seeing this David Tudor, Pauline Oliveros system way of thinking, which seems like you're in the mix like you are a fundamentally part of this kind of complex system, it's noisy, it's big, it's beautiful. Related to that studio practice. And then I really loved Xenakis and like this intense full work
Yeah, with my hands in the moment, like, so this idea of being able to have my hands and also like, you know, learning the xenakis aesthetic, but also the notion about acousmatic playing.

hands on the mixer, hands on the equalizer really is a performance of an instrument, bringing things to life, but I want to go further with that. I want to engage like that with my hands on the sound, but where it's a much more complex web of processes like the Oliveros tutor stuff.

So digital technology was the way to do that. For me to. This this complex amalgam of granular stuff, you know, granular textures. Of of feedback and interrelationship of things that can come back overtime.

There's, there's a lot of parallels just in that uh, that studio based performance, you know, performing the studio and then, you know, leading to an instrument and then this broader, you know, bubble of studio instrument.

What modes are still there and what aren't there until I did that? And then I watched my video as well. So that was interesting. OK, so I've always been a big fan of developing a system and then freezing it. Even if you want to do other things and playing it for a while
That's just like, you know, work with the limitations of it. Take notes in the comment boxes within Max. I've got the history of comment boxes all over the place in, in the system that I find later

And so it did get to a point where it froze, you know, 2010 ish or so, and it incrementally changed. But it froze in a large way and just felt really good. And then it was more the space of performance. I was engaging with, which vaulted vaulted into a lot of questions. Then there was a point both. It was like, inefficiencies that had gathered up over time. It was. I was relying on FTM for some stuff. I started getting overly reliant on JAMOMA

That wasn't working, so there was a bunch of things that I was becoming over reliant on and it was clunky. And I was, you know, inefficient. The other one is the UM… This kind of long form thing about doing this the the like recording, pressing the button recording and then that being a multi layered object that is control data as well as sound data. But then I'm like, oh, OK, well, mubu is lining that all up and Oh my God, it's now connecting with catart, which I put down because of FTM, etcetera, etc.

Let me start to like the play module. Let me pull this apart and pull little bits apart and then put them back together again with the mubu playback database, kind of the the database stuff structure built into it central, so that that was really the impetus for redoing it. And then that that drove me to think, OK, well then I could get new controllers because it's always been about the mapping, the metaphor and the sound, and then working backwards.

How it works like I can't get rid of the Wacom, nor do I want to and this is me getting to the gesture metaphor and this kind of by manual thing. I can talk more about, but I have always wanted to be able to set the pen down, have two hands

What drew you to MACHINE LEARNING and those Technologies
Well, two things. One, one, I think, I mean everybody guess it's fascinated about new things. It was definitely one of the main reason

But I would also say it was a need a really embedded need on my way of working. I was using very traditional way of composing and I started to find out that it was not.Not very expressive for me to build everything from scratch in the sense like my the real. The main reason why I moved to machine learning was because my approach to mapping. A controller with with some sound processes became too much rational and too much. As you say you would. Cerebral

I don't know the term in English, but you really had to plan. focus more on music and expression than mathematics

So that was the reason. The need and of course, fascination for things.
describe your experience using machine learning, so maybe even kind of going in a bit of choosing the gestures and making that relationship

Yeah. So I I would start like just saying mentioning that the the object or the system that I was using before using machine learning is nodes the the object nodes in max that gives you some kind of preset interpolation between different. You know position in space

from there I started to find out that this idea of machine learning for for what I use like at the moment, the algorithm that I mostly use is linear regression. So it basically gives me control over continuous data so that I can. Record a, not a gesture yet, but I can record a position or a state, a fixed state in time and a fixed sound in time.

So what I mean with that is that I can decide and say this is my position #1 and I want to associate this position with a specific sound that I search and as I was saying in the reflection. I get very interested by using some kind of random system that allows me to to have a more open, reduced kind of listening of the sound and then as soon as I find something that tracks my attention, I try to. If there is a high pitch sound like very dense kind of sound then you know my my hands could be you know opening so I can for example record this position and have that sound associated with this position. And once I iterate.

This process of training set like recording and training sets of gestures and sound. Then I will have a kind of space in which I can move around and while with the nodes object, if you would. Have. A. Two points like 1:00 and 2:00. You could interpolate between .1 and two, but if you would go out of these two points, you would have emptiness, right? You don't have anything but what machine learning and this tool that I use in. Max.

You don't have anything but what machine learning and this tool that I use in. Max. Even if you record 2 gestures. Which is point A&B and and you go you know you do something different and you don't interpret these two, you still are going to find a new sound there. You know what I mean? So that's to me it's very powerful and it's very inspiring.

And I think that my approach to machine learning switch The attention and the approach of instead of being 100% fully conscious of what I want and what I'm looking for, I leave my ear more open to what the machine suggests me, and then I can reflect upon suggestions of the machine learning system and then a dialogue becomes between the two. And I can say yes, I like what you're suggesting and I want to fix this or no, I don't like it. And I'm gonna move on.

The randomness aspect (in digital instrummental systems contexts) becomes another layer to explore ther relatinoships between varous subsystems and perhaps super-systems along with (more) causal relationships (linear causal? || nonlinear causal). When exploring the relationships of scale in nonlinear causal structures (?) 'randomness' provides layer to the exploration. There is something in this that perhaps is relating to the complimentary aspect of (in)determminismm, or, there is only so much randomm before order merges...

You know, taking like steal from another training set of another performance and use it with other kind of sound and other space. And even I try, you know, to switch with other people, our training sets and I will play their own gestures into into my system and and vice versa so.

the goal is to try as much as possible to play, so I would know more or less where I am like if at the beginning I don't have a clue like once I make for the first time a training set of gesture and sound of eight gesture and eight sounds, I don't know what I'm going to discover.
more play system more like acoustic

The more I play in the space, the more I become acquainted and it feels like if you would be an acoustic instrumentalist that you know, the more you play with the instruments, the more you know how your hands should be, how much energy it's going to produce, which sounds so the more I play with it and.
I would say the more performance I do with the system The piece, like the more probably the piece, will become structured or at least give more an idea of a piece
structure piece based on gesture/choreographed movement towards "tradition piece"

It's very tricky to define a piece in terms like, usually in the traditional composition you have a structure, you have a beginning, you have an end. But in my case there is. I mean I I try to reuse some kind of gestures that I'm used to, like slowly raising my hand, you know, to control volume of a sound, then some kind of quick movements or some other choreographically movements, but. Apart from that, I'm really still trying to define my own set of gestures and movements and make it a more probably traditional kind of piece.
open question - how to define a work/performance
But still, yeah, it's an open. It's an open question to me.
...intrigued by the intersection between design, composition and improvisation

I think it's very related to the second point that I try to address is when a a MIDI controller or even any controller interface becomes an instrument with which you can play. So this is where I'm I'm now like I'm at the at the at the path in which I build a system that gives me these possibilities of mapping.

I build an an an interface that gives me this possibility of movement of control. I have 8-10 buttons in my hand, And I do some kind of strategies because the previous setup I had many more buttons, many more knobs and fader. And with these two balls [controllers] I I had to somehow restrict and, you know, lessen the way of control. So I had to find strategies like divide the roll.. Axis in few channels

So every channel I have different nodes that I can control so that I can multiply control and so on. But. The moment in which I will shift from having wearing an interface with playing an instrument is where I'm now. So the more I will play and the more I will have feedback from from what I do, the more it will become fun to play and good to play.
… what ways would you consider it not an instrument at the moment
what makes an instrument an instrument
That's a good, good question. I mean, there are a lot of reasons why it's not an instrument, but I think the main core of this question is what makes an instrument an instrument.

And right in my case, like I can get a lot of interesting functions, but it feels like now it's more. You know, it's feels like it's a disassembled instrument or not fully assembled yet, right? Like, if you have flutes that has three pieces, like I only have two connected in a kind of weird place.

So still need to find a way to block it and give it a shape, but I think that what makes an instrument an instrument, another controller is that it gives you control over Your musical intentions, but it also allows to be open to unpredictable kind of outcomes, right? So if you play in a specific way that you and you were expecting a sound to come out, something slightly different happen and you react to it, you try to adjust to it and there is a dialogue between.
what makes an instrument an instrument

What are you doing? What are you thinking and musically are interested in to doing and what the instrument responds to your action and when when this relationship is established, then I think. You're closer to an instrument than a controller than a than an than a simple interface.

This is a great point -- the combination and space for defining and executing musical intention entangled with the space and emphasis of unpredicatable outcomes --- this seems to be the stark difference from acoustic instrument… developing interaction to express musical intention in dialogue with unpredicatable (yet musically interesting under ones broader intentions - intention across scale)
… further describe 'latencies' as mention in your reflection (machine, interface, body…)

It's a risky word latencies because they mean something, but it also doesn't mean anything like in this context. What I'm trying to say is that. I'm always trying to since my background is very traditional and have been trained not to make mistake, never fail, do everything you know 100% and I found myself more thinking of how to move and how to, you know, adjust my body posture than really focusing on what I was playing and.
question of mistakes from a 'neatly' built system?

This kind of training And this, you know, it was Very radical from where I was coming from and it wasn't really suiting me and that's why I started to say And much more interested in what are the mistakes of my body and what which kind of mistakes comes out from a system that you build so neatly in a computer.

I mean also if you think about sound, what makes the sound beautiful to our ear is not a pure, I mean it can be a pure sine wave, but if you start to add some kind of distortion or a slight in pitch different, the tuned voice, it's there that you start to be interested in in the sound and say ohh look this.
beauty in mistakes, failure, errors during process

It's something different than a pure sine wave, right? So I I I feel about latencies as a kind of. You know, procedural mistake of you know, our body of the movements. Like if I played Theremin and I do a slight, you know, if I move slightly forward then the pitch changes completely. But this is also part of, you know, it might be also part of the beauty of a performance this kind of Mistake, error and failure during the process. So I I try to embrace what happens.

And try to turn this failure and latencies of, you know, our body the way it moves the way there is so much. Sometimes there is so much distance between an idea and what your body can do and really express there is sometimes a huge a huge space. And also, you know speaking about latencies of a machine machine In at, of course, now it's very fast.

But sometimes, like as I experienced in my first try out, I had a lot a lot of dropouts, a lot of. But you know, this is another topic, but I would have been very curious to hear to the results of this, you know, condensation of sound that the the 1st 5 minutes you remember. So I was really curious to see which kind of music Came out from me.
… how would you describe ohh as you know being able to express your intent.
In that case, of course, like, oh, it's a system that allows me to create these kind of mappings. So to create this kind of association between my posture and the and the sound and.

It allows me To do this in a pretty you know I. I even started to the sound design and just the design session within a performance. So try to set up some position and then play around them. So I find out that this system allows me to.

You know, create a decent way of expressing my movement and my musical intention through my interface. So in this case, like this, O is very set up for my interface, but it can be used with a simple core nano control or any kind of MIDI controller of course.
draw circle - change size/speed - different intention

But in this way, like I couldn't really find a better way than using this linear regression algorithm to give me this control over continuous sound. As a next step, I think that it would be very interesting to find out how just the following and just the follower would work. So if I draw a circle like this is more thinking about gestures and intentions. Like if I make it more circle. And I want this circle to be associated to a specific kind of sound word. And if I make this circle wider or faster then you know this has different intention, right? In my case I managed to get a very simple and tight, you know, piece of software that allows me to, you know.
complementing sound with different sound through gesture

I hear a sound that is very low frequency, very bass, and to me suggests you know, not too much tension, but rather some call calm movement so that I could, you know. Program with sound to be related. When my hands are just relaxed. And then if I want that if I found a brighter sound, like a sound that becomes more brighter and even higher pitch, then I can open my hands and this intention for me from opening and rising from something very low to something open and bright red gives me this kind of close.
gives me this kind of close. Relationship between my intention, which is, you know to open up a different kind of sound word or close it down once again, right?

So to this extent, I think that my system allows you know very basic. Gesture mappings with the with sound, but there is still so much to to investigate and there are, but it's very it's a very potential. I would say and and. It's very nice to play with.
...the relationship or not you see between improvisation and indeterminism and randomness

so in improvisation and randomness. Well, there are definitely 2 distinct, you know methods. They're both great. I think in my case and in my system I use randomness more in a compositional side where I try to, you know, remove every pre concept from what I'm looking for and be open to what. The system would suggest me and then once I hit through randomness, some points that I'm really curious and interested about
randomness - no link to previous state

In terms of performance and live improvisation. You know you are. There is always feedback like, with randomization randomness you don't have any feedback. like you don't have like a point after you know if you if you have Button that gives. You the most random outcome that you would expect and you hit this button again.
randomness - no link to previous state
There is almost no Link with what happened before right while in and in in, in, in an improvisation there is always some kind of feedback coming in. In play. It can be a sound feedback and.

You know you can if you want to link, you know, a sudden sound you might want to link it with silence before right? Or if you want to have more noisy part it needs to be probably, you know preceded by a more calm scenario in order to give you. You know, kind of the diversity throughout the performance, so it it can't be randomness, live improvisation and improvisation can't be randomness. I think. I mean can can be everything can be. So I'm not saying that it can't be but.
stay away fromm conscious action [perception-action loop]

In my approach, I tend to to get. I try to be open like open ears, open hands and try to be open to feedback. So to what comes back to me and the way I react. So I don't really. I don't really make too many conscious actions actually. Like what I really like and what the system allowed me is that once I create my system.

I can feel free in a space and there are no preconception there is no, you know, a good play or a bad way. There is not a good way or a bad way to play. But there is a system in which you can play and it doesn't matter if you make mistake or if you don't. From your point of view. But of course the more you play and the more you think about an audience. Like how the audience is going to absorb. Understand. What are you doing? So there is a balance, of course, between between these two. Points.
Do you include your sound gesture design process in performance?

I I did that a few times. I did that as a few time. And like it works if it is clear like now I don't like even in the performance that I sent you last time. I just loaded my training sets and I played with what I already used as a just sound mapping. But I think it's very fascinating to show the audience that you are in the middle of an empty set, you know, and you're starting over with with your, with your own system.

And so I did that and I I would say I will do it again probably when I will have everything under control and it might be clear to the audience that I'm building the system, but then I will have to find the turning point between this is the end of sound design and this is the beginning of performance or. You know, try to combine and blend them together.
Further describe the random sound selection process

Alright. Yeah, it's. I mean, it's funny to. It's a nice question that to me it it became such an embedded process that I don't even think about it. You know I'm I'm trying to really go, you know in in your position between a traditional way of, You know, usually a composer has already in mind which kind. Of. Music they want to play and they just need to put it on a paper and and it's there, right? In my case, it's either the opposite or it's, you know, a different kind of way. And I.

I Try to blank. Out my head and say, OK, this is what I have. And I simply have a button. For, I mean, in my system it has different layers, but let's say if we go global I have my small let's say setup in which we have few buttons and few options to tweak randomness so that it becomes you know more probabilistic kind of movement and.

I have said, And and actually as a small parentheses. I even made this random system a generative system to play with in in terms that there are some envelopes for the sounds for my, For my sound processes and my synthesizers parameters that each one of those is mapped to one, let's say dial or one control and this random button basically shifts everything and I can change the weights of you know is it run like random walk?

So I want to really. You know, move very finely through this kind of randomness. Or do I want to change over completely? Or do I want to, you know. I can hit the bottom and leave this random process for a while to change very smoothly and very gradually, and then there is another button which is stop and or like 4. I say to go back. How do you say?

Like not forward. Yeah, to reverse back. And I can go back if something you know, sleeper my mind and I can go back and say, OK, this is the sound that I like and then I record and I saw a preset of of these, you know, dials and then I move on again and then I click this sound and I add this not this. The button of random. Oneness and I leave its, you know, flow and discover. I mean, I'm very interested about the combinations of these parameters and.
leave system to scrub/scroll through random possibilities

And I leave and I leave this and I leave the system to scrub or scroll through as many possibility as possible and it can be either fast movement or a very slow movement. And as soon as I. As he finds it like a store it.
does randomness come into your system in other ways

Well, I still have this random button embedded in one of the button of my ball, just in case. I know there are some moments in which I want to introduce, you know, once I explored a lot of ways and place, I just want to, you know, have something new and also with the roll access I can change how fast. And how slow this random process work like moves moves so it can. Be either super. Fast, you know, changes or it can be very slow random changes.

But I think that. Run like this process of randomizing my system my let's say synthesizer with 12 parameters it it takes a longer time for for it to be presented in a performance I think because. Before coming becoming aware of the sound that you're interested into, you might take and actually it's a. It's a beautiful process because you know you really have a reduced listening and.

You you're just there for one hour and you just listen to the sound without really giving too much. Too much, too much conscious definitions or categorization, you just, you know, try to be to absorb as much as possible and there is always this kind of gap between being completely fascinated with what happens. And then you say, OK, stop.
randomness has a beauty in performance

I'm conscious and I'm gonna choose these. Right? So it's you're always trying to fade in and fade. Out through the world of, you know, really enjoying the sounds and the and the music and then making compositional decisions and during a performance everything is faster. You have to choose quickly what to do. And so randomization for now it's more for me it's compositional part like the first phase. But I think it has also a beauty in in terms of performance.
